channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Adventure Awaits! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl People with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Perl Programmer Opportunity - Join a Prominent Tech Publishing Powerhouse in the Philippines
item.description: Our UK-based client is a global leader in the enterprise technology publishing industry, providing audiences worldwide with stimulating perspectives and unique news on enterprise tech that matters today and tomorrow. They are currently seeking a passionate and exceptional Perl programmer based in the Philippines to join their team.

item.title: Programming language popularity on Reddit
item.description: I was interested how different programming languages are doing on social networks and social platforms. This time I looked at the popularity of the Subreddits.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report.

item.title: Lotteries and sequences
item.description: Keep it sweet and simple to get the job done. Cool attempt.

item.title: 25 or 6 out of four… ty-nine
item.description: Just love the different approaches to solve a task. So much to learn from it, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 246
item.description: Perl one-liner by one of the masters of one-liner. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Brute Force Math!
item.description: Use of brute force method can be handy at times. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 246: Linear Recurrence of Second Order
item.description: Keeping the solution simple and straight forward both in Perl and Raku. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 246: 6 out of 49
item.description: Classic one-liner in Raku is must to watch out. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Recurring Lotteries
item.description: Nice cool new format blog post thorough discussion. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Make It Unique
item.description: Discussion styled post is so fun to read. Always pleasure, highly recommended.

item.title: Uniquenes
item.description: Graphical representation to present the internals. Kudo for your effort and well done.

item.title: Random use of algebra
item.description: Perl one-liner is showing off the power. Nice work, keep it up.

item.title: Out of Linear
item.description: Bonus solutions this week as we got not just Raku but many more. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Peter Meszaroa
item.description: Please checkout the interview with the latest weekly challenge champion, Peter Meszaros.

item.title: Meet The Champion - BarrOff
item.description: Little late though, finally we have interview with the champion, BarrOff is public now.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 246
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "6 out of 49" and "Linear Recurrence of Second Order" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 247
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Secret Santa" and "Most Frequent Letter Pair". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Revisit Perl programming after 20 years
item.description: Using Perl to code a generative language model.

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell): September - October 2023
Day 9: Mooish Attribute Shortcuts For Everyone!
Day 8: Who's That Clicking At The Window?
Day 7: HTML/XSS scrubbing and file upload validation in Catalyst
Day 6: Arango::Tango, the new mammal in town
Day 5: Santa's Christmas Dancer2 Web App - Naughty & Nice List Manager
System Thinking
item.description: Although not Perl sepcific but the topic is worth sharing. Please do checkout.

item.title: Is Perl a write only language?
item.description: Use of Perl in the field of Bio-Informatics. Encouraging story to share.

item.title: Building a Micro-SaaS in 30 Days
item.description: Real life example of building Micro-SaaS project. Highly recommended.

item.title: Rust Maven
item.description: Rust is, in a way, orthogonal to Perl. It is a rather verbose language with a steep learning curve. However it is much faster than Perl and can be cross-compiled and easily distributed. It provides memory safety though it takes time to get used-to the ownership model. On the other hand it makes it rather easy to write threaded applications. I've been writing about Rust for a while on the Rust Maven site. You are invited to subscribe to the Rust Maven newsletter!

item.title: Ruth Holloway Candidacy for Board Membership
item.description: Presenting Ruth Holloway as a candidate to join the Board with voting on 15th Dec 2023.

item.title: Bruce Gray Candidacy for Board Membership
item.description: Presenting Bruce Gray as a candidate to join the Board with voting on 15th Dec 2023.

item.title: This week in PSC (126) | 2023-11-30
item.description: Three Perl releases have been published this past week, containing patches for security issues CVE-2023-47038 and CVE-2023-47039.

item.title: #646 - Festive Season
item.description:
Hi there,

December is normally the busiest month of the year as we get to participate in two events i.e. 24 Pull Requests and Advent Calendars for many programming languages e.g. Perl, Raku, The Weekly Challenge. As mentioned in the weekly newsletter by Gabor Szabo, there is an aggregation of Advent Calendars managed by Len Jaffe.

In the last edition of newsletter, I requested for sponsor. To my surprise, I have had few offers came through. It is still early stage of discussion. I am hopefull something positive will come out of it. I am keeping fingers crossed.

Have you contributed to Perl Advent Calendar 2023?

If not then you should and share your real life experience with Perl. You can find the details on GitHub repository. I missed the deadline last year but this year I really didn't want to miss the train. Luckily, thanks to Olaf Alders and team, my contribution got accepted and merged. It is now allocated Day 10 in the calendar.

Enjoy the fesive season and look after yourself.
item.dc:subject: editorial
